abstract.p: Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corp chairman Albert C Wiltshire letter on May 29 article cites organization's many contributions to Bedford-Stuyvesant community

block.p: A May 29 news article characterized the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn as a community that has ''receded into the shadows'' and the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation as an ''impediment to progress.'' This characterization is unfair. Restoration's contributions to central Brooklyn are many. A May 21 Real Estate section article said brokers consider Bedford-Stuyvesant a ''gold mine'' and credited Restoration as one reason for its progress.

A May 29 news article characterized the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn as a community that has ''receded into the shadows'' and the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation as an ''impediment to progress.'' This characterization is unfair. Restoration's contributions to central Brooklyn are many. A May 21 Real Estate section article said brokers consider Bedford-Stuyvesant a ''gold mine'' and credited Restoration as one reason for its progress.

The corporation has made more loans to businesses in Bedford-Stuyvesant than any other entity and has contributed thousands of dollars to local charities. More than 1.5 million people visit Restoration Plaza every year to benefit from its services -- a supermarket, a theater, two banks and a computer tech center, among others. We have provided 37 local entrepreneurs with formal training in less than two years. These achievements do not impede progress; they engender it.
ALBERT C. WILTSHIRE Chairman, Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation Brooklyn, June 2, 2000
